MARKET RECAP

Desks noted the move was exacerbated by a multi-month, record size, equity buy programme, leading to speculative selling in the belly to long end; a chunky block steepener was recorded, with 26.7k TUH contracts bid and 5.3k USH contracts offered. US T-note (H0) futures settled 19+ ticks lower at 128-13+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 16th December 2019: “Christmas rally” puts SPX on 3200’s door as US-China deal dust settles
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 16th December 2019: “Christmas rally” puts SPX on 3200’s door as US-China deal dust settles

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude flat/up

* REAR VIEW: Large risk appetite as Phase One deal set for January signing; US and EZ services PMIs impress, whilst EZ manufacturing slump continues; Chinese activity data tops expectations

* COMING UP: RBA minutes; UK jobs data; US building permits and housing starts, industrial/manufacturing output, jolts; API inventories; GDT auction. Speakers: ECB’s Lane; Fed’s Kaplan (2020 voter), Williams (voter), Rosengren; BOE’s Carney.

 

* MARKET WRAP: The three major US indices opened at record highs, extending their gains after a Phase One agreement between US & China was reached on Friday, leaving expectations for a signing in January, barring any issues. Desks noted a large equity buy programme, the largest since early October, helping bourses find their “Christmas rally” and seeing speculators offering duration in the Fixed Income complex. All sectors traded in the green, technology lead the outperformers at the open, boosted by Semiconductors (SOX) after the trade-sensitive space saw a positive mention from JPMorgan and a few individual stock upgrades (WDC, MU) from Susquehanna; Energy was the outperformer despite crude’s modest gains. Industrials was an underperformer following reports Boeing (BA) is considering halting or cutting production of its 737 MAX, but again still marginally in the green amid the widespread equity bid, although it did lead the DJIA to considerately underperform both SPX and NDQ. Flash PMI data failed to see any price action, however Markit’s manufacturing print ticked down slightly as expected to 52.5 from 52.6, New orders also declined to 53.2 from 53.6. Services however fared better as it rose to 52.2, beating expectations for a rise to 51.8 from 51.6, and the new business index also ticked up to 52.4 from 51.2. This mornings EZ data continued to show a worry in the manufacturing sector, however the pick-up in services reassured participants that the manufacturing isn’t quite seeping into other sectors.

* US/CHINA PHASE ONE 'DEAL': Analysts have highlighted that the 'deal' between US and China is very light on details; China has not had to commit to a specific monetary value of us ags purchases, and the 'deal' lacks an enforcement mechanism. In return the US has agreed to roll-back some tariffs on Chinese imports. Some have suggested that this was far less progress than the market was expecting, and while the 'deal' will likely be signed off in January by both countries (we now revert back to monitoring where the meeting will take place, and whom the deal will be signed by; the latest updates suggest it will take place in Washington in January, and will be signed off by USTR Lighthizer and China Vice Premier Liu He), thus preventing any immediate trade war escalation (in theory), a fully-fledged deal remains a long way off -- possibly until after the Presidential Elections in November 2020. However. ING warns that in the interim, market uncertainty on the actual content/implications of the deal may continue to be fuelled by more contradictory newsflow on the matter.

* US EMPIRE STATE MANUFACTURING (DEC): The headline rose by less than expected to 3.5 (exp. 4.0, prev 2.9), the headline was underpinned by a solid showing for shipments, but new orders remains weak and employment held steady, Oxford Economics noted; "weaker domestic and global growth as well as trade policy headwinds are keeping persistent pressure on regional manufacturing activity. However, the forward-looking components were more encouraging; expectations rose by 10.4 points to 29.8, and OxEco sees the potential for a material acceleration in manufacturing activity in 2020.

* US ADVANCE DEC PMI: The manufacturing PMI fell one-tenth to 52.5, as expected, while the services PMI topped expectations at 52.2 (exp. 51.8, prev. 51.6), helping to bump the composite to 52.2 from 52.0. Markit said the surveys were a welcome sign the economy was continuing to regain growth momentum; the outlook also brightened, as did business activity, order book and jobs growth, which all ticked up to five-month highs, buoyed by rising domestic sales and further signs of renewed life in export orders. Markit said that business activity expectations lifted higher in both sectors, rising to the highest since June, which suggests that the expansion will continue to gain momentum; the optimism reflected reduced fears over trade wars and more favourable financial conditions. With that said, Markit stated that the brighter news needs to be caveated, as the overall rate of economic expansion signalled by the surveys remains well below that seen this time last year, commensurate with GDP rising at an annualised rate of just over 1.5%. "Importantly, however, the welcome signs of improvement help to ward off recession risks and should keep the Fed on hold in the coming months," and "the upward trajectory in the surveys support our expectations that the US economy is on course to see another year of above potential GDP growth of approximately 2.2% in 2020.”

* USMCA: Over the weekend, the USMCA was facing fresh setbacks, with Mexico's top negotiator Seade dismissing claims that Mexico would be subject to labour enforcement inspections from other nations as part of the deal; Seade tweeted "Mexico will NEVER accept any measure that would see inspectors disguised for a simple reason: Mexican law prohibits it," and in another tweet adding with emphasis "NO INSPECTORS" - some of his tweets were later deleted. The labour provisions within the deal were a sticking point for Democrats. On Monday, however, the Mexicans were keen to signal the debate over inspectors did not put USMCA at risk, and that it was up to Mexico to accept diplomatic labour attaché that US Congress proposed. The USTR issued a statement in response which noted that five labour attaches would work with Mexico to implement the reforms which would abide by Mexican law, adding the labour verifications would be conducted by independent panellists, not labour attaches.

* CHINA/GERMANY TRADE: China has threatened to retaliate against Germany if Huawei was banned from supplying equipment to Germany's 5G telecoms network, with the Chinese ambassador to Germany highlighting German auto exports to China as a potential target.

* EZ ADVANCE DEC PMI: EU Markit Composite Flash PMI for December printed 50.6, unchanged from the prior and marginally below the expected 50.7. Manufacturing fell to 45.9 from 46.9, missing the expected rise to 47.3, whilst Services rose to 52.4 from 51.9, above the expected 52. Survey compiler Markit said the EZ economy has been stuck in crawler gear for fourth straight months, with the PMI indicative of GDP growing at a quarterly rate of just 0.1%. Other analysts noted that the weakness isolated to manufacturing, not services, could indicate domestic demand is remaining resilient, after concerns last month; and the composite index remained unchanged, an encouraging sign.

* GERMANY ADVANCE DEC PMI: Manufacturing Flash fell to 43.4 (Exp. 44.5, Prev. 44.1), services rose in line with expectations to 52.0 from 51.7, and the composite was unchanged at 49.4 against an expected rise to 49.9. Pantheon Macroeconomics' analysts said that the only bright spot in these data was that the rate of contraction in manufacturing new orders is now easing, though the overall downtrend is still more than enough to offset a higher new business intake in services; new orders are falling in the private sector as a whole. "This discrepancy carries over to the other details too," PM writes, "work backlogs and employment are still sliding overall, thanks to weakness in manufacturing, a trend that is feeding through to prices," and adds that "both input and output price inflation have collapsed, especially in the industrial sector, and finally, the outlook for production and new orders over the next 12 months improved, though mainly in services."

* CHINESE INDUSTRIAL: For November Y/Y printed 6.2%, beating the expected 5.0% and up from the prior 4.7%. SocGen’s analysts highlight both the growth in manufacturing and mining output improving, whilst utilities remained steady, “The warmer-than-usual weather looked to be a supporting factor, as did the more lenient production controls for the winter. Altogether, looking through the monthly volatility, last month’s improvement took the average for October and November to 5.1%, up from 5.0% in 3Q, i.e. still an indication of activity stabilisation.”

* ECB: Weidmann (hawk) appeared to dial down his hawkishness in an interview with Sueddeutsche Zeitung, stating that the government's commitment to a balanced budget should not become a "fetish", and also appeared to temper his opposition to proposals for including climate change as part of the ECB's mandate, though he added that central banks cannot make climate policy themselves. ECB VP de Guindos said the lower for longer interest rate environment creates strains on profitability of banks, with implications for financial stability, and added that the latest indicators point to a stabilization of economic activity. Meanwhile Holzmann (hawk) said he sees a possible ECB rate change in the event the inflation trough passes during 2020.

* US T-NOTE (H0) FUTURES SETTLED 19+ TICKS LOWER AT 128-13+. The TPLEX exhibited pronounced bear steepening, lead by the belly, on Monday as investors got long on risk assets as the dust settled from the US-China Phase One announcements. Desks noted the move was exacerbated by a multi-month, record size, equity buy programme, leading to speculative selling in the belly to long end; a chunky block steepener was recorded, with 26.7k TUH contracts bid and 5.3k USH contracts offered. By settlement the 10-year yield was just shy of 1.9%, up over 6bps on the session, whilst the 2-year yield rose just 4% to 1.64%, seeing the 2s10s widen over 2.5bps; the 2s30s widened a less pronounced ~1.7bps.

* FED REPO OPERATIONS: The NY Fed’s 32-day repo operation was slightly oversubscribed, with USD 54.25bln bids submitted versus USD 50bln offered. Meanwhile, the overnight operation was well under-subscribed, with all USD 36.40bln in bids accepted. Monday had been marked as a potential pressure point within the repo and funding markets, since it falls on both a Treasury auction settlement date and corporate quarterly tax payment date, in an echo to the prior “blow-up” in September; however the GC opened up at 1.7% (within the FFR target) which helped to alleviate some concerns of such an event on Monday, but risks remain heading into the critical year-end period, analyst said, while BMO reminds us that over 40% allocation to MBS collateral serves as a reminder that funding needs extending well beyond the Treasury market, even on days with a USD 54bln net coupon settlement.

* PBOC MLF: The 1-year MLF rate was kept unchanged at 3.25%, and the PBOC added a small injection on Monday. The Ministry of Finance also said it would issue CNY 10bln 6-month offshore bills on 20th December.

* AUSSIE MYEFO: The Treasury's 2019/20 growth forecast was unchanged at 2.25% in its mid-year economic and financial outlook, while wage growth forecast was lowered to 2.50% from 2.75%; 2019/20 budget surplus view was narrowed to AUD 5bln (around 0.3% of GDP) from 7.1bln, while the 2021 surplus estimate remained at AUD 6.1bln (prev. forecast was AUD 11.0bln), and over a four-year horizon, the budget was narrowed by AUD 22bln, which was more than expected. Elsewhere, the issuance profile was also lowered in the next financial year, though does rise over the rest of the forecast horizon. UBS said it expects further tax cuts in May, but there is downside risk to its forecast of AUD 10bln in household tax cuts, and that reduced capacity for fiscal stimulus likely supports its expectation of further RBA easing ahead; the Bank sees the RBA cutting its cash rate further next year, pencilling in a 25bps reduction in February, and another 25bps cut in to 0.25% by mid-2020.

* WTI (F0) SETTLED USD 0.14 HIGHER AT USD 60.21/BBL; BRENT (G0) SETTLED 0.12 HIGHER AT USD 65.34/BBL. Crude benchmarks edged higher to start the week as participants digested the Phase One US-China trade deal announcements and some positive Chinese activity data in the Asia session. There was little in the way of energy-specific market updates, with sentiment being carried from the China deal, in addition to the recent OPEC+ production cut deal in the background. Note that WTI (F0) options expire on Monday, book squaring could have been an element of the session’s tape action. Looking ahead to this week’s inventories expectations (bbls): Crude stocks -1.9mln, Gasoline +2.1mln and Distillate +0.2mln.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.7% at 3191, NDX +1.0% at 8570, DJIA +0.4% at 28236

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Semiconductors (SOX) performed well today after the sector gained a positive mention at JP Morgan, who forecast further upside in 2020 as industry growth rates inflect positively and drive a positive earnings revision cycle; The same analyst, Harlan Sur, noted the top pick in the space is Broadcom (AVGO), citing its underappreciated diversification and strong FCF and dividend growth, highlighting Nvidia (NVDA), Intel (INTC), Micron (MU) on strong data centre exposure, Qorvo (QRVO), Marvell (MRVL) as key 5G plays and Texas Instruments (TXN) and Microchip (MCHP) on improving industrial/cyclical trends. Elsewhere, Micron (MU) and Western Digital (WDC) also benefitting from upgrades at Susquehanna. Boeing (BA) weighed DJIA after reports stated the jet manufacturer is considering halting or cutting production of its 737 MAX jet as there are further concerns regarding the return of the jet.  Apple (AAPL) traded firmer after a positive mention at Cleveland Research, who are optimistic on the stock citing strong iPhone revenues and its quickly accelerating wearables business. International Flavours and Fragrances (IFF) traded lower after DuPont (DD) it is to merge its Nutrition & Bioscience unit with IFF. DD holders will hold 55.4% of the combined company and will receive a onetime USD 7.3bln special cash payment when the deal is closed. DuPont (DD) initially opened higher however the majority of gains pared throughout the session. Uber (UBER) traded higher after it is reportedly in talks to sell its UberEats India business to a local rival. Tesla (TSLA) also performed well following a positive note from Credit Suisse, with the analyst a noted bear, saying, “Tesla is leading in the areas that will likely define the future of car making-software and electrification”. However, the EV maker saw some selling pressure after a senator stated an electric car tax credit is unlikely in a spending deal. Goldman Sachs (GS) also traded firmer after an upgrade at Citi. Elsewhere, Amarin (AMRN) traded higher after its Vascepa, a drug used to reduce cardiovascular risk, received FDA approval; whereas BeiGene (BGNE) fell roughly 8% after its phase 3 ASPEN trial failed to meet its primary endpoint.

* FX WRAP: CNH pared some of Fridays losses and USDCNH trades back beneath the 7.00 handle amid a firmer midpoint fix by the PBoC last night and constructive comments from the Global Times noting the exchange rate will remain stable due to promising domestic growth. Strong industrial output data last night likely also helping the Yuan. DXY traded in the red today as it moved below the 97.00 handle, although resides just above it going into ASIAPAC trade after the index saw a turnaround from lows of 96.93 following strong NAHB data. Markit PMI data did little to move the buck as it fell largely in line with expectations, although the Markit services PMI was firmer than expected. EUR traded firmer today despite mixed EZ PMI’s, which saw a poor manufacturing print, but services were slightly firmer than expected. The single currency broke 1.1150 to the upside continuing its run from last week and paring back Friday’s downside. GBP traded firmer against the buck, and weaker against the EUR after a set of poor PMI’s and a stalling of the post GE rally. However, Cable still trades around the 1.33-1.34 mark after paring some of initial post-election gains which saw the cross trade as high as 1.35 in the election aftermath. Havens were mixed against the buck with JPY weaker today amid no further catalyst however rate differentials are likely playing a factor amid rising US yields. XAU traded flat as it traded in a very tight 6 buck range around the 1475 level. EMFX were generally firmer against the buck with outperformance seen in BRL & ZAR, with the latter likely benefitting as no further load shedding was reported. TRY, the underperformer, after renewed angst on the Turkish-US relations front and USDTRY edging closer to technical resistance beyond 5.8500.

subject: EUROPEAN PRELIMINARY CASH CLOSE: EURO STOXX 50 (+1.09%) at 3772, FTSE100 (+2.23%) at 7517, DAX (+0.92%) at 13405, CAC 40 (+1.23%) at 5992, IBEX 35 (+1.20%) at 9678, FTSE Italia(+0.84%) at 23525, SMI (+1.02%) at 10446
Daily FX Wrap: PMIs provide passing interest on otherwise mundane Monday
content:
USD

Not even a healthy NAHB beat was able to give the flagging Dollar a boost after the DXY only mustered enough strength to peer momentarily over the 97.000 handle before returning to its narrow 97.153-96.926 confines in wake solid Markit flash PMIs. The Greenback and currency market in general are still weighing up the details of US-China trade accord part one divulged so far, or perhaps more importantly the significance of what has not been said like exactly how much agricultural products Beijing has pledged to buy and whether Washington is willing to withdraw more tariffs.

EUR/AUD/NZD/CAD

All on the front foot vs the Usd, with the Euro ending a relatively sombre start to the last full week of the year among the top major performers alongside the non-US Dollars even though preliminary Eurozone PMIs were less impressive overall, and in the case of Germany’s manufacturing sector just plain bad. However, Eur/Usd managed to breach 1.1150 at best, while Aud/Usd edged a bit closer to 0.6900, Nzd/Usd held around 0.6600 and Usd/Cad was capped below 1.3150 for the most part.

GBP/CHF/JPY 

A weak set of UK PMIs and some stalling of GE momentum kept the Pound in check after early rallies in Cable to around 1.3422 and within a few pips of 0.8300 vs the single currency. Sterling also awaits Friday’s Parliament vote on PM Johnson’s Brexit withdrawal deal with baited breath, but in the interim some hard data and more immediately the BoE’s FSR. Meanwhile, the Franc continues to meander between 0.9845-20 parameters and hold up better than the Yen (like Gold) that is more correlated with US Treasury yields and now under 109.50 eyeing recent lows as 109.71 and 109.73.

NOK/SEK 

The Norwegian Krona has lost momentum having failed to extend gains through 10.0100 against the Euro, but its Swedish peer still looks capable of rebounding further within a 10.4465-4140 range given a widely anticipated ¼ point Riksbank tightening move this Thursday.

EM

The Yuans have reclaimed 7.0000+ status with the aid of a stronger PBoC midpoint fix and constructive sounding comments in China’s Global times claiming that the exchange rate will remain stable due to promising domestic growth (after IP and Retail Sales beats) and expectations that the external environment turns more stable. On that note, wires report that the USTR and China’s VP will sign off on Phase 1 in early January. Conversely, the Lira suffered renewed angst on the Turkish-US relations front and Usd/Try is edging closer to technical resistance beyond 5.8500.

content: • The three major US indices open at record highs extending its gains after a Phase One agreement between US & China was reached on Friday where expectations are for a signing in January, although it is unclear whether it will be presidential or not. Trade sensitive technology lead the out performers to start the session being driven by Semiconductors (SOX) which is the leading GIC sub-sector, which had a positive mention from JP Morgan this morning. Financials and Energy are also an outperformer on the back of the higher yields and energy prices respectively. On the down side, utilities the underperformer given the defensive nature of the sector, albeit still marginally higher. Industrial's also an underperformer following reports Boeing (BA) is considering halting or cutting production of its 737 MAX, but again still marginally in the green,

analysis_details: • Over the weekend, the USMCA was facing fresh setbacks, with Mexico's top negotiator Seade dismissing claims that Mexico would be subject to labour enforcement inspections from other nations as part of the deal; Seade tweeted "Mexico will NEVER accept any measure that would see inspectors disguised for a simple reason: Mexican law prohibits it," and in another tweet adding with emphasis "NO INSPECTORS" - some of his tweets were later deleted. subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt remains mixed and Dollar muted
content: Not much reaction to the NY Fed PMI, as the headline read was close to consensus and sub-components pretty evenly split in terms of changes from previous levels. However, bonds are still somewhat divergent with Gilts outpacing Bunds and both doing considerably better than USTs, while the Greenback is still broadly softer vs currency rivals, bar the marginally underperforming Jpy. Ahead, flash Markit PMIs, ECB QE tallies, NAHB and the UK’s latest FSR.

content:

  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is reportedly considering reducing production or halting production of its 737 MAX over continued uncertainty regarding its return to service, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • DuPont de Nemours Inc (DD) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) is to merge its Nutrition & Biosciences business with International  Flavours (IFF) (Materials/Chemicals) where DD shareholders will own 55.4% of the combined company, and DD will receive a  onetime USD 7.3bln special cash payment in closing of the IFF deal. Following the deal DD sees 2019 operating EBITDA at the low  end of its guidance range. Executive Chairman Ed Breen says they have some interesting bolt on opportunities they like in the  company and don’t plan to sit on cash, may do bolt-on M&A.
  • Amarin Pharmaceuticals (AMRN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) received FDA approval for its Vascepa, to reduce cardiovascular  risk.

 

16th December 2019

  • Of note for US Casino Names (MGM, WYNN, PENN, LVS, BYD), Barclays is bullish on the sector heading into 2020 where analyst Felicia Hendrix believes it could be poised for further growth next year.
  • Of note for Semiconductors (SOX), JPMorgan forecast further upside in 2020 as industry growth rates inflect positively and drive a positive earnings revision cycle. Analyst Harlan Sur notes the top pick in the space is Broadcom (AVGO), citing its underappreciated diversification and strong FCF and dividend growth. The analyst also highlights Nvidia (NVDA), Intel (INTC), Micron (MU) on strong data centre exposure, Qorvo (QRVO), Marvell (MRVL) as key 5G plays and Texas Instruments (TXN) and Microchip (MCHP) on improving industrial/cyclical trends. Also of note, RBC highlight unconfirmed reports that Samsung (SSNLF) will invest roughly USD 8bln in its second semiconductor plant in Xian, China, citing Business Korea. RBC also highlight unconfirmed reports that Intel’s is expecting to reach 1.4nm designs by 2029, with 7nm in 2021, 5nm by 2023, 3nm by 2025, 2nm by 2027. The desk notes that if this leaked information is correct, it implies a two-year node reduction cycle.

DOW

  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is reportedly considering reducing production or halting production of its 737 MAX over continued uncertainty regarding its return to service, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • Coca-Cola Company (KO) (Consumer Staples/Soft Drinks) announced its Senior Vice President and Chief Growth Officer, Francisco Crespo, will retire in 2020 after 30 years with the company.
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has its Erleada for treatment of patients with metastatic castration-sensitive prostate cancer approved by Health Canada after a priority review.
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) increased its quarterly dividend to USD 0.38/share from USD 0.36/share, a 6% increase.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) streaming product, Disney+, will launch on Vivendi’s (VIV FP) Pay-TV business Canal+ by the end of March.
  • United Health Group Inc. (UNH) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) has been upgraded to Conviction Buy from Buy at Goldman Sachs, where analyst Stephen Tanal highlighted its attractive commercial business, which holds top market share position in Medicare Advantage, and a top three position in Medicaid. The analyst states > USD 19bln in operating cashflow next year will “handily cover” its USD 2.3bln worth of capital expenditures, which puts the company in a good position to deploy capital against earnings growth vie tuck-in acquisitions and share repurchase programmes. Stephen Tanal increased the PT to USD 330 from USD 300.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) and Flipkart are to invest in a Bangalore based fresh produce supply chain start up named Ninjacart, the financial terms were not disclosed, however Economic Times citing people familiar with the matter, state WMT could invest up to USD 50mln.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class A (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) self-driving business, Waymo, acquired Latent Logic, a spinout company from Oxford University which specialises in imitation learning, helping machines learn from human actions. The financial terms were not disclosed, although it gives Waymo its first presence in the UK. (The Guardian)
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) Ring is to introduce new security features after hackers broke into a child’s bedroom and had the ability to watch and talk to the child. (Business Insider)
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) had tens of thousands of its employees personal banking information compromised after a thief stole several corporate hard drives from an employee’s car.
  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) had its PT raised at USD 56 from USD 48 from Morgan Stanley ahead of its earnings on Wednesday, where analyst Joseph Moore noted the recent memory chip strength is surprising and should bring short-term momentum back into the name.

S&P 500

  • Dollar General (DG) & Dollar Tree (DLTR) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) is being asked by local governments across the country to provide fresh food amid a lack of grocery stores. (WSJ)
  • DuPont de Nemours Inc (DD) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) is to merge its Nutrition & Biosciences business with International Flavours (IFF) (Materials/Chemicals) where DD shareholders will own 55.4% of the combined company, and DD will receive a onetime USD 7.3bln special cash payment in closing of the IFF deal. Following the deal DD sees 2019 operating EBITDA at the low end of its guidance range. Executive Chairman Ed Breen says they have some interesting bolt on opportunities they like in the company and don’t plan to sit on cash, may do bolt-on M&A.
  • Humana Inc. (HUM) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) is to acquire Enclara Healthcare, although financial terms were not disclosed.
  • Lilly (Eli) & Co. (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced a global commercialisation agreement to join DexCom (DXCM) products into LLY’s diabetes management system, adding it is currently in development to advance the treatment of diabetes.

OTHER

  • Amarin Pharmaceuticals (AMRN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) received FDA approval for its Vascepa, to reduce cardiovascular risk. Following the approval, it increased its FY19 revenue forecasts to (USD) 410-425mln (exp. 410.25mln, prev. 380-420mln. Updates FY20 revenue guidance to 650-700mln (exp. 654.55mln)
  • BeiGene (BGNE) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced its Phase 3 ASPEN trial did not meet its primary endpoint as it did not achieve statistical significance when comparing BTK inhibitor BRUKINSA to ibrutinib for the treatment of Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia.

CHK acknowledged the notice, adding they intend to regain compliance by pursuing measures in the best interests of the companies.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer this morning, though the FTSE 100 significantly outperforms on a second-wave of UK election optimism
  • China State Council stated it will continue to suspend additional tariffs on US vehicles and auto parts due to the Phase One deal
  • China sources cited by CNBC's Yoon note that the USD 40-50bln target on agricultural purchases is a "best case target"
  • Boeing (BA) is mulling cutting or stopping its 737 MAX production, via WSJ – Co. shares are down 2% pre-market
  • USD remains subdued vs. most G10 peers, although Sterling and Euro were dented on the Flash PMIs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Flash PMIs, ECB’s Lane, de Guindos, BoE’s Carney (Financial Stability Report)

TRADE

On Sunday, China State Council stated it will continue to suspend additional tariffs on US vehicles and auto parts due to the Phase One deal, whilst also suspending the addition 5-10% tariffs on some US goods planned to take effect on December 15th, according to CNBC’s Yoon (Twitter)

China's Foreign Ministry states that more trade information will be released in due course and working-level officials from both sides remain in contact. (Newswires)

China sources cited by CNBC's Yoon note that the USD 40-50bln target on agricultural purchases is a "best case target", and that the US would likely allow 'best endeavor' purchases; adds that general feeling on tariff rollback is an issue of linguistics. (CNBC) Additionally CNBC’s Yoon adds, no Chinese confirmation regarding the hard targets for US agricultural purchases; although, China is likely to agree but cannot acknowledge this publicly due to a possible backlash. (Twitter)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed following relatively light newsflow over the weekend and last Friday’s flat performance on Wall St. where the major indices consolidated near record levels after the confirmation of a US-China Phase One deal which officials plan to sign in early January, although some noted the deal was only limited and questions arose over the feasibility of China committing to as much as USD 50bln of US agriculture goods. ASX 200 (+1.6%) was lifted by outperformance in defensives and the top-weighted financials sector with sentiment buoyed after the world’s 2 largest economies averted the December 15th tariffs, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) was subdued by the recent pullback in USD/JPY and as the latest Japanese Manufacturing PMI data remained in contraction territory. Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) were constrained despite the phase one agreement confirmation and better than expected Chinese data in which Industrial Production and Retail Sales both topped estimates, as the stats bureau stated the economy still faces relatively big downward pressure and amid expectations for a reduced growth target for next year, while the mood in Hong Kong was also soured by a rise money market rates (Overnight HIBOR +57bps) and the resumption of violent protests over the weekend. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with prices hampered by last week’s resistance levels and with demand also subdued due to the absence of the BoJ in the market today.

PBoC skipped reverse repos but conducted CNY 300bln 1-year MLF operations at 3.25%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9915 vs. Exp. 6.9937 (Prev. 7.0156)

China stats bureau said the economy still faces relatively big downward pressure and that China will keep economic operations within a reasonable range, while it also commented that China is able to reach full-year growth target and its economy remains resilient but faces rising external uncertainties. (Newswires)

US expelled 2 Chinese Embassy officials suspected of espionage following an incident in September in which the officials and their wives improperly drove onto a military facility in Virginia. (WSJ) Subsequently, on these reports, China’s Foreign Ministry states that the relevant allegations are false. (Newswires)

Chinese Industrial Output (Nov) Y/Y 6.2% vs. Exp. 5.0% (Prev. 4.7%). (Newswires) Chinese Retail Sales (Nov) Y/Y 8.0% vs. Exp. 7.6% (Prev. 7.2%) Chinese House Prices (Nov) Y/Y 7.1% (Prev. 7.8%)

US

Senate Democrats proposed a week-long Senate impeachment trial seeking testimonies from 4 new witnesses including John Bolton and Mick Mulvaney over President Trump's conduct towards Ukraine, according to reports citing a newly released document. (AP)

GEOPOLITICS

Turkey President Erdogan threatened to shut down 2 bases in the country including the Incirlik Airbase where the US military stores nuclear weapons, if sanctions are placed on Turkey. (Newswires)

North Korea is said to have conducted another test at its long-range rocket site which it said would strengthen its nuclear deterrent, although it is unclear if this was a missile test, while it added that hostile forces including US should refrain from provocation if they want to end the year peacefully. In related news, US Special Rep. for North Korea Biegun said it is regrettable that the tone of North Korea statements has been hostile, and that the US doesn’t have a deadline on negotiations with North Korea but instead has a goal. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is looking for a parliament vote on Brexit before Christmas to get it done by the exit deadline of January 31st. In related news, senior UK Cabinet Minister Gove reiterated pledge for the UK to have a trade deal with EU by end of next year despite reservations in Brussels whether this is feasible, while other reports noted senior Brussels sources said the EU will not “cut its own throat” with a post-Brexit trade deal next year if PM Johnson refuses to align Britain’s economy to single market rules. (Newswires/Times)

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn will stay on as party leader until the end of March. (Politics Home)

 

Fitch affirmed France at AA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Spain at A-; Outlook Stable. DBRS maintained UK rating at AAA with Stable Trend. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Dec) 45.9 vs. Exp. 47.3 (Prev. 46.9)

-        Services Flash PMI (Dec) 52.4 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 51.9)

-        Comp Flash PMI (Dec) 50.6 vs. Exp. 50.7 (Prev. 50.6)

-        IHS Markit state ‘PMI indicative of GDP growing at a quarterly rate of just 0.1%’

 

UK Flash Services PMI (Dec) 49.0 vs. Exp. 49.5 (Prev. 49.3)

-        Manufacturing PMI Flash (Dec) 47.4 vs. Exp. 49.3 (Prev. 48.9)

-        Composite PMI (Dec) 48.5 vs. Exp. 49.6 (Prev. 49.3)

-        HIS Markit state, the latest decline in the data "increases the likelihood that the economy contracted slightly in the fourth quarter"

 

German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Dec) 43.4 vs. Exp. 44.5 (Prev. 44.1)

-        Services Flash PMI (Dec) 52.0 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 51.7)

-        Comp Flash PMI (Dec) 49.4 vs. Exp. 49.9 (Prev. 49.4)

 

French Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Dec) 50.3 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 51.7)

-        Markit Services Flash PMI (Dec) 52.4 vs. Exp. 52.1 (Prev. 52.2)

-        Comp Flash PMI (Dec) 52 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 52.1)

EQUITIES

European equities kick-start the week on the front foot [Eurostoxx 50 +0.7%] following on from a relatively mixed APAC session, with traders citing an overall improvement in the trade environment as a reason for the advances.  Cash Stoxx 600 (+1.1%) managed to notch intraday record highs, albeit the FTSE 100 (+2.1%) stands as the marked outperformer amid further post-election tailwinds on large-cap stocks, miners benefitting from rising copper prices and exporters taking advantage of a declining Sterling – Standard Chartered (+3.3%), RBS (+3.2%), Barclays (+3.5%), Glencore (+4.0%), BHP (+3.2%), Rio Tinto (+2.9%) and Antofagasta (+2.7%). DAX and other core European indices stalled gains amid disappointing December Flash PMIs. Sectors opened modestly in positive territory but have since gained traction, with cyclical Materials and Financials outperforming on the back of FTSE 100 gainers. In terms of other individual movers, Novartis (unch) opened lower after the Co. stated it will be dropping development of its asthma drug amid a string of disappointing trials. Meanwhile, Kerry Group (-3.5%) shares fell to the foot of the pan-European index after losing a USD 26bln deal to International Flavours and Fragrances for US-listed DuPont’s nutrition division (+1.9% pre-market). Last but not least, Sports Direct (+20%) soared on the back of a profit jump with group revenue increasing 14% YY which comes amid performance woes after the Co. acquired the troubled House of Fraser.

Boeing (BA) is mulling cutting or stopping its 737 MAX production. (WSJ) – Co. shares are down 2% pre-market

FX

GBP/EUR - Sterling’s post-UK election 2nd coming was already fading after a fleeting foray above 1.3400 vs the Dollar and test of resistance around the psychological 0.8300 level against the single currency when the preliminary PMIs for December confounded expectations for some improvement and missed consensus by quite a distance, especially in the manufacturing sector. Cable duly retreated towards 1.3325 and the cross rebounded to circa 0.8350 even though the earlier Eurozone flash surveys were also disappointing, and Germany’s manufacturing headline in particular. However, Eur/Usd remains depressed within a 1.1123-50 range and may struggle to pull away from decent option expiries between 1.1120-25 and 1.1100-10 (1.2 bn clips) rather than challenging slightly larger interest at 1.1150 (1.3 bn).

NZD/CAD/AUD - All firmer vs their US counterpart that continues to flounder (DXY anchored around 97.000), with the Kiwi keeping tabs on the 0.6600 handle, Aussie hovering just under 0.6900 and Loonie pivoting 1.3150 in wake of some upbeat Chinese data overnight (ip and retail sales) and further reserved reflection on US-China trade deal Phase 1. Nzd/Usd and Aud/Usd have both regrouped after losing some ground on independent impulses via growth forecast downgrades from the NZIER and government respectively, while the former also took note of Westpac rolling its RBNZ rate cut prediction to August next year from February.

NOK/SEK - The Scandi Crowns are both holding firm lines ahead of this week’s Norges Bank and Riksbank policy meetings, but Eur/Nok’s retreat is more technical after breaching the 100 DMA (10.0385) compared to Eur/Sek’s reversal through 10.4300 in anticipation of a 25 bp repo rate hike on Thursday.

CHF/JPY - The safe-haven Franc and Yen are narrowly mixed against the Buck, with Usd/Chf nearer the bottom of a 0.9825-45 band in contrast to Usd/Jpy hovering just below 109.50 compared to 109.25 at one stage and flanked by expiries between 109.00-05 and 109.50 in 1bn.

EM - Against the grain of broad rallies vs the Dollar, Usd/Try is nudging 5.8500 and an upside chart objective at 5.8671 amidst heightened Turkish-US angst after President Erdogan’s threat to shut NATO bases if Washington decides to impose more sanctions.

Australia cut 2019/20 economic growth forecast to 2.25% from 2.75% and lowered wage growth forecast to 2.50% from 2.75%, while it sees 2021 budget surplus at AUD 6.1bln vs. Prev. forecast AUD 11.0bln, according to the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook. (Newswires)

Westpac pushed back its RBNZ rate cut forecasts in which it now sees a 25bps cut in August 2020 from Prev. forecast of a cut in February 2020. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries, Ny Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1065-75 (800M), 1.1085 (600M), 1.1100-10 (1.2BLN), 1.1120-25 (1.2BLN), 1.1150 (1.3BLN), 1.1180 (516M), 1.1200 (1.5BLN)

-        USD/JPY: 109.00-05 (1BLN), 109.50 (1BLN)

FIXED INCOME

Based on the scale of price movement more than action or precise timing, Gilts appear to have been at the forefront of the recent downturn in debt futures along with Italian BTPs following extended gains in wake of the preliminary PMIs to 132.12 (+59 ticks on the day) and 172.43 for Bunds (+33 ticks). In truth, Treasuries have resisted any temptation to rebound or piggy-back their EU peers and remain underwater with the curve steeper, so could be exerting more influence as attention switches to the US open, while short term/intraday techs may also be a factor as the nearest bullish chart targets were not breached or really threatened.

COMMODITIES

Little to report on the commodities front - with WTI and Brent futures largely unchanged on the day, albeit in positive territory after a relatively flat APAC session. WTI futures trade on either side of USD 60/bbl whilst its Brent counterpart topped USD 65/bbl in recent trade with little by way of fresh fundamental catalysts, and with participants somewhat cautious of the US-China Phase One deal amid a lack of details and a paucity on China’s commitments. Elsewhere, gold prices remain choppy within a tight USD 5/oz range thus far, as traders and investors await further Phase One details. Copper meanwhile has resumed its upwards trajectory with risk-sentiment a cited factor, although upside may be more due a receding USD and above-forecast China industrial production and retail sales. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures fell in excess of 1.5% after data showed weekly utilisation rates at 163 mills across China slumped almost 66 – thus casting fresh doubts on demand for the base metal.

subject: French Pensions Reform Tsar resigns
analysis_details: • Tuesday will be a critical date amid mass protests being scheduled by labour unions. UBS' analysts note, "Both positions seem gridlocked at the moment, neither gaining nor losing support, so with the holiday period approaching, it could break either way." The bank believes that the turnout n Tuesday will determine the governments path, where the government is scheduled to present the reform bill by Friday against the labour unions wishes, who want it all removed.

Bunds: pivoting parity pre-Eurozone preliminary PMIs and more ECB speak
content: A relatively inauspicious start to the final full trading week of 2019, as the core bond flits either side of last Friday’s 172.10 close in a narrow 172.21-06 range awaiting the return of cash bourses and then flash PMIs ahead of 2nd tier data in the form of Q3 labour costs and wages. A couple more ECB speakers also scheduled after the first post-meeting press conference/Q&A from Lagarde and typically hawkish remarks from Holzmann earlier. Back to Eurex, volumes are notably thin following inflated turnover from last Wednesday onwards and in particular after the UK election and Phase 1 US-China trade pact announcements.

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

16th December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed following relatively light newsflow over the weekend and last Friday’s flat performance on Wall St. where the major indices consolidated near record levels after the confirmation of a US-China Phase One deal which officials plan to sign in early January, although some noted the deal was only limited and questions arose over the feasibility of China committing to as much as USD 50bln of US agriculture goods. ASX 200 (+1.6%) was lifted by outperformance in defensives and the top-weighted financials sector with sentiment buoyed after the world’s 2 largest economies averted the December 15th tariffs, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) was subdued by the recent pullback in USD/JPY and as the latest Japanese Manufacturing PMI data remained in contraction territory. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were constrained despite the phase one agreement confirmation and better than expected Chinese data in which Industrial Production and Retail Sales both topped estimates, as the stats bureau stated the economy still faces relatively big downward pressure and amid expectations for a reduced growth target for next year, while the mood in Hong Kong was also soured by a rise money market rates (Overnight HIBOR +57bps) and the resumption of violent protests over the weekend.

Foreign Owned Co’s – EU’s Competition Chief Vestager is reportedly examining methods of curbing unfair competition via foreign state-owned Co’s; which comes as EU state are seeking enhanced scrutiny of Chinese Investment within Europe. (FT)

FTSE 100

Lloyds (LLOY LN) – Co. is said to have launched internal investigation into a leak the disclosed GBP 770mln in compensation claims to 4.37mln customers. (Newswires)

LSE (LSE LN) – McCarthy is to reportedly become COO, replacing Corado., according to sources. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

 

BROKER MOVES

 

DAX

Wirecard (WDI GY) – Co’s CEO states that they has a ‘tremendous 2019’ which is a ‘good indication for a very strong 2020’. (Newswires/Twitter)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

CAC

EDF (EDF FP) – Co. has unveiled a plan, which includes EUR 100mln of spending, to restore trust in the French nuclear industry. (FT)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Wendel Investissement (MF FP) – Co. completed sale of stake in Allied Universal for net cash proceeds of USD 721mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

European Co’s  - US is reportedly weighing 100% tariffs on more EU products including whiskies and Cognac amid the fallout of its Airbus (AIR FP) dispute according to CNBC citing documents, while the new items being considered for tariffs up to 100% range from Spanish olive oil and French Swiss cheese to Irish and Scotch whiskies. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

subject: ECB's Holzmann (Hawk) sees a possible ECB rate change in the event the inflation trough passes during 2020
Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 16th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed following relatively light newsflow over the weekend, ASX 200 outperformed
  • USTR Lighthizer said China agreed to purchase USD 40bln of agriculture in the first year, added the deal will be signed by trade principals in Washington in the first week of January
  • US is reportedly weighing 100% tariffs on more EU products including whiskies and cognac amid the fallout of its Airbus dispute
  • In FX, the DXY was lacklustre, GBP/USD benefitted from a mild post-election second wind, PBoC fixed USD/CNY reference rate below 7.0000
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ, UK and US Flash PMIs, ECB’s Lane, de Guindos, BoE’s Carney

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed following relatively light newsflow over the weekend and last Friday’s flat performance on Wall St. where the major indices consolidated near record levels after the confirmation of a US-China Phase One deal which officials plan to sign in early January, although some noted the deal was only limited and questions arose over the feasibility of China committing to as much as USD 50bln of US agriculture goods. ASX 200 (+1.6%) was lifted by outperformance in defensives and the top-weighted financials sector with sentiment buoyed after the world’s 2 largest economies averted the December 15th tariffs, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) was subdued by the recent pullback in USD/JPY and as the latest Japanese Manufacturing PMI data remained in contraction territory. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were constrained despite the phase one agreement confirmation and better than expected Chinese data in which Industrial Production and Retail Sales both topped estimates, as the stats bureau stated the economy still faces relatively big downward pressure and amid expectations for a reduced growth target for next year, while the mood in Hong Kong was also soured by a rise money market rates (Overnight HIBOR +57bps) and the resumption of violent protests over the weekend. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with prices hampered by last week’s resistance levels and with demand also subdued due to the absence of the BoJ in the market today.

PBoC skipped reverse repos but conducted CNY 300bln 1-year MLF operations at 3.25%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9915 vs. Exp. 6.9937 (Prev. 7.0156)

USTR Lighthizer said China agreed to purchase USD 40bln of agriculture in the first year with best efforts to increase that to USD 50bln, while he confirmed there will be additional negotiations and that the December 15th tariffs are cancelled. Lighthizer added the deal will be signed by trade principals in Washington first week of January and he does not expect a presidential signing, while he also stated it is China’s expectation that there will be further phases and further reductions in tariffs. (Newswires)

On Sunday, China State Council stated it will continue to suspend additional tariffs on US vehicles and auto parts due to the Phase One deal, whilst also suspending the addition 5-10% tariffs on some US goods planned to take effect on December 15th, according to CNBC’s Yoon (Twitter)

China stats bureau said the economy still faces relatively big downward pressure and that China will keep economic operations within a reasonable range, while it also commented that China is able to reach full-year growth target and its economy remains resilient but faces rising external uncertainties. (Newswires)

US expelled 2 Chinese Embassy officials suspected of espionage following an incident in September in which the officials and their wives improperly drove onto a military facility in Virginia. (WSJ)

Chinese Industrial Output (Nov) Y/Y 6.2% vs. Exp. 5.0% (Prev. 4.7%). (Newswires) Chinese Retail Sales (Nov) Y/Y 8.0% vs. Exp. 7.6% (Prev. 7.2%) Chinese House Prices (Nov) Y/Y 7.1% (Prev. 7.8%)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is looking for a parliament vote on Brexit before Christmas to get it done by the exit deadline of January 31st. In related news, senior UK Cabinet Minister Gove reiterated pledge for the UK to have a trade deal with EU by end of next year despite reservations in Brussels whether this is feasible, while other reports noted senior Brussels sources said the EU will not “cut its own throat” with a post-Brexit trade deal next year if PM Johnson refuses to align Britain’s economy to single market rules. (Newswires/Times) UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn will stay on as party leader until the end of March. (Politics Home)

US is reportedly weighing 100% tariffs on more EU products including whiskies and Cognac amid the fallout of its Airbus (AIR FP) dispute according to CNBC citing documents, while the new items being considered for tariffs up to 100% range from Spanish olive oil and French Swiss cheese to Irish and Scotch whiskies. (Newswires)

DBRS maintained UK rating at AAA with Stable Trend. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed France at AA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Spain at A-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Dec) M/M -0.9% (Prev. -1.3%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (Dec) Y/Y 0.8% (Prev. 0.3%) 

FX In FX markets, the DXY was lacklustre and trickled back towards the 97.00 level after EUR/USD mildly rebounded from support at 1.1110 and GBP/USD benefitted from a mild post-election second wind with UK PM Johnson reportedly looking for a parliament vote on Brexit before Christmas to get it done by January 31st deadline but failed to break through resistance at 1.3400. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses languished after their recent pullback, and antipodeans were also subdued after failing to profusely capitalize on the firmer CNY reference rate as well as encouraging China data. In addition, the latest Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook for Australia showed the government cut the current fiscal year growth forecast to 2.25% from 2.75% and reduced its wage growth estimate by 25bps to 2.50%, while NZIER lowered New Zealand 2019/20 GDP growth forecast to 2.2% from 2.3%.

Australia cut 2019/20 economic growth forecast to 2.25% from 2.75% and lowered wage growth forecast to 2.50% from 2.75%, while it sees 2021 budget surplus at AUD 6.1bln vs. Prev. forecast AUD 11.0bln, according to the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook. (Newswires)

Westpac pushed back its RBNZ rate cut forecasts in which it now sees a 25bps cut in August 2020 from Prev. forecast of a cut in February 2020. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures traded sideways slightly below the USD 60.00/bbl amid the indecisive overnight risk sentiment and lack of fresh catalysts to spur further advances after having extended in its quarterly high last week. Gold was also little changed and failed to benefit from the mild USD weakness, while copper mirrored the humdrum tone across the complex with only mild short covering observed as demand as some doubts remained despite the phase 1 agreement and better than expected Chinese data.

Baker Hughes Rig Count Oil +4 at 667, natural gas -4 at 129 and total unchanged at 799 rigs. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Turkey President Erdogan threatened to shut down 2 bases in the country including the Incirlik Airbase where the US military stores nuclear weapons, if sanctions are placed on Turkey. (Newswires)

North Korea is said to have conducted another test at its long-range rocket site which it said would strengthen its nuclear deterrent, although it is unclear if this was a missile test, while it added that hostile forces including US should refrain from provocation if they want to end the year peacefully. In related news, US Special Rep. for North Korea Biegun said it is regrettable that the tone of North Korea statements has been hostile, and that the US doesn’t have a deadline on negotiations with North Korea but instead has a goal. (Newswires)

 

US 

Fed's Williams (Voter, Neutral) said the housing market is picking up from a year ago and consumer spending is strong, while he expects the US economy to grow by about 2% over the next couple of years and suggested low and stable inflation isn't a concern but wants to avoid falling inflation. (Newswires)

Senate Democrats proposed a week-long Senate impeachment trial seeking testimonies from 4 new witnesses including John Bolton and Mick Mulvaney over President Trump's conduct towards Ukraine, according to reports citing a newly released document. (AP)

PBoC - PBoC was said to plan MLF operation today. (Newswires)

Protests - Violence broke out again in Hong Kong over the weekend where police and protestors clashed as small groups targeted some shopping centres. (Newswires)

Trade

US President Trump tweeted that US has agreed a Phase One deal with China in which December 15 tariffs will not go ahead and that the sides will begin negotiations on the Phase Two Deal immediately rather than waiting until after the 2020 Election. Furthermore, President Trump announced the US would be maintaining the existing 25% tariffs which currently covers USD 250bln worth of Chinese imports and will cut the remaining tariffs which currently stands at 15% on USD 125bln of Chinese imports to 7.5%, while he later stated that he thinks China will hit USD 50bln in US agricultural purchases. (Newswires)

USTR Lighthizer said China agreed to purchase USD 40bln of agriculture in the first year with best efforts to increase that to USD 50bln, while he confirmed there will be additional negotiations and that the December 15th tariffs are cancelled. Lighthizer added the deal will be signed by trade principals in Washington first week of January and he does not expect a presidential signing, while he also stated it is China’s expectation that there will be further phases and further reductions in tariffs. (Newswires)

USTR press statement noted the US will be maintaining 25% on approximately USD 250bln of Chinese imports along with 7.5% tariffs on approximately USD 120bln of Chinese imports, according to Axios. (Twitter)

China Foreign Minister Wang Yi said a Phase one US-China agreement is major good news for the entire world. There were also separate comments from China's Vice Commerce Minister that the US will follow through on its promise to cancel tariffs on a phased basis and that the agreement is consistent with China's goal of reform, while China's Vice Finance Minister said China has decided to cancel tariffs scheduled for Sunday and that both sides agreed not to impose the Sunday tariffs. (Newswires)

China Global Times warned agreement on the text of the US deal does not mean that all trade issues can be resolved and any “accidents” could happen during the implementation citing experts, while an expert close to China's Commerce Ministry also stated the US tariff rollback is a goodwill gesture which is an improvement but is not enough. (Twitter)
